title: Why Vietnam Ignored Its Own Laws to Fast-Track a Trump Family Golf Complex
content: As President Trump blurs the lines between politics and business — and threatens steep tariffs on trade partners — governments feel compelled to favor Trump-related projects.

title: Qatari Push to Dominate Another Sport, Table Tennis, Draws Scrutiny
content: A wealthy Qatari businessman’s campaign to lead the sport’s global body is being investigated. One of his critics was detained and interrogated in Doha.

title: In the Shadow of a Tainted Election Steal, Maduro Asks Venezuelans to Vote Again
content: Some in the opposition say the only way to protest is to abstain. Others say doing so will let the government “say they won without resistance.”

title: Venezuela Is Holding an Election in Essequibo, a Region of Neighboring Guyana
content: In Sunday’s election, President Nicolás Maduro has called to elect a governor of Essequibo — a region that actually belongs to neighboring Guyana.

title: North Korea Arrests 3 Over Failed Ship Launch That Angered Kim Jong-un
content: Three shipyard officials were arrested, including the chief engineer, state media said. The North Korean leader was watching as the launch of a navy destroyer went wrong.

title: Trump’s Warming Toward Syria Complicates Israel's Military Strategy
content: Since Mr. Trump’s embrace of the new Syrian leader, Israeli airstrikes on the country have subsided.

title: Selfies From the Front: Inside the ‘V.I.P.’ Brigade for Ambitious Russian Officials
content: After a stint with a drone unit led by a member of Parliament, Russian officials return to work, and promotions, garlanded as war veterans. Most soldiers are stuck in indefinite deployments.

title: Europe’s Been Negotiating by the Book, but Trump’s Tearing It Up
content: The Trump administration sees tariff talks as a chance to pressure a rival into concessions. E.U. officials have acted as though they were dealing with an ally.

title: Israel’s Campaign to Win Eurovision Went All the Way to the Top
content: Government social media accounts and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu joined a campaign to encourage people to vote for Israel’s entrant.

title: In the Midst of War, a Tale of Hot Dogs
content: Nathan’s Famous has found a foothold in Ukraine, a hot dog-loving country.

title: Hong Kong’s Famous Bamboo Scaffolding Hangs On (for Now)
content: Metal has begun to replace this distinctive latticework, which is seen on towers across the city. Daisy Pak, a rare female bamboo master, takes pride in the ancient craft.

title: Hamburg, Germany Stabbing Victims in Stable Condition, Police Say
content: The police said they believed the violence, which injured 18 people during Friday’s evening rush hour, was not politically motivated.

title: How an Iconic Blouse Became the Center of a Political Tussle in Romania
content: Nationalists in Romania have adopted an item of clothing traditionally worn by villagers, particularly women. Liberals say it’s an appropriation of a cultural identity that belongs to everyone.

title: In Attacks on Harvard, Chinese See Yet Another Reason to Write Off the U.S.
content: Beyond the shock for students, President Trump’s moves against higher education are being seen in China as a blow to one of the last admirable American institutions.

title: Russia Bombards Ukraine With One of Largest Air Assaults of the War
content: The attack involved nearly 370 missiles and drones, according to Ukraine’s Air Force. At least 12 people were killed.

title: Inside a Trump Family Project in Vietnam
content: As President Trump blurs the lines between politics and business — and threatens steep tariffs on trade partners — governments feel compelled to favor Trump-related projects. Damien Cave, Vietnam bureau chief for The New York Times, and Katrin Bennhold, a senior writer on the international desk, discuss how this dynamic has played out in Vietnam, at the groundbreaking of a fast-tracked $1.5 billion Trump golf complex.

title: The Israeli Connections to a New Gaza Aid Plan Promoted as Independent
content: Foreign contractors are set to carry out a contentious new food aid system in Gaza, displacing experienced aid agencies like the United Nations. It was conceived and largely developed by Israelis as a way to undermine Hamas.

title: Power Outage in Cannes During Film Festival Is Sabotage, Officials Say
content: An arson attack and damage to a transmission tower cut off power in the area, the authorities said. The festival’s closing ceremony on Saturday is scheduled to proceed normally.

title: Working Out
content: Reorganizing your week just might make it possible to reorient your relationship with time.

title: Canada’s Central Banker on Economic Turmoil and Diversifying Trade
content: We spoke with Tiff Macklem, the governor of the Bank of Canada, after a meeting of top economic policymakers in Alberta.

title: Russia and Ukraine Exchange Air Assaults Amid Major Prisoner Swap
content: The hourslong raids, involving hundreds of drones, were a reminder that any diplomatic resolution to the conflict remains far off.

title: Teachers Protest in Mexico City Shuts Down Airport
content: Flights were briefly halted, delaying travel for thousands, as security forces swarmed into passenger terminals in an effort to assert order.

title: Trump Signs Executive Orders for Faster Build-Out of Nuclear Power Plants
content: Among a flurry of executive actions, Mr. Trump directed the nation’s nuclear safety regulator to speed up approvals for new reactors.

title: Knife Attack at Train Station in Hamburg, Germany, Wounds at Least 17
content: Four of the victims are in critical condition. The police say they believe a 39-year-old woman carried out the attack, for which no motive has yet been given.

title: Lebanon Moves to Disarm Palestinian Groups, a Test Run for Hezbollah
content: After war with Israel weakened Iran-backed militias across the Middle East, including the Lebanese group Hezbollah, Lebanon’s government has moved to assert its authority over armed groups.

title: Paris Court Convicts Eight in 2016 Robbery of Kim Kardashian
content: The reality TV star, who was held at gunpoint as jewelry worth millions was stolen from her, said she was satisfied by the ruling.

title: Sebastião Salgado, Acclaimed Brazilian Photographer, Is Dead at 81
content: Known for his powerfully impactful images of nature and the human condition, he was widely regarded as one of the most important documentary photographers of his time.

title: Historic Shipwrecks Come to Light in the Great Lakes
content: With an underwater drone named Rhody, archaeologists are mapping some of the dozens of sunken vessels in Lake Ontario.

title: American Emigration to Britain Rises
content: New data from the U.K. government showed applications surged in the first three months of this year, which some analysts attributed to the political climate in the United States.

title: Yuri Grigorovich Dead: Soviet Ballet Choreographer Was 98
content: Among the 20th century’s most significant choreographers, he led the Bolshoi Ballet for more than 30 years, creating epic ballets like “Spartacus.”

title: South Africa Sets the Stage for Starlink Approval
content: A proposed regulatory change would allow Elon Musk’s satellite company and others like it to get a license without having to sell shares to Black South Africans.

title: Bangladesh’s Leader Threatens to Resign Over Election Pressure
content: Muhammad Yunus has struggled to navigate between the army, career politicians and the protest movement that overthrew the country’s authoritarian leader last year.

title: Trump Threatens 50% Tariff on E.U. and 25% Tariff on Apple
content: The president threatened both Apple and the European Union with higher tariffs on Friday, saying trade talks with the Europeans had stalled.

title: Ukraine and Russia Begin Largest Exchange of Prisoners of War
content: Each side reported that 390 of its people had been returned, and more swaps are expected this weekend.

title: How to Understand Trump’s Latest Deportation Tactics
content: This week saw a dramatic court showdown and a mysterious flight to Djibouti.

title: In ‘Cancer Alley,’ a Battle Over Who Gets to Measure Air Pollution
content: Community groups are fighting an unusual Louisiana law that restricts how they use data from air-quality monitors, saying it violates free speech.

title: At an Uncertain Moment for Germany, Suddenly Boring Doesn’t Look So Bad
content: The small city of Bielefeld was once the butt of jokes for its blandness. Now it embodies the kind of stability Germans long for.

title: As Trump Demands More Military Spending, NATO Allies Reconsider What Counts
content: The president has long pressed European allies to pay more for their own security. So they may redefine what qualifies as security.

title: Syrians Rush to Preserve Remembrances of a Painful Revolution
content: Many in Syria want to enshrine remnants of their recent history, not only to remember it, but as a cautionary tale.

title: New Studies Dismiss Signs of Life on Distant Planet
content: In April, astronomers said they had detected a possible signature of life on the exoplanet K2-18b. Now, three independent analyses discount the evidence.

title: Friday Briefing
content: Here’s what you need to know.

title: Trump Confirms Attempted Deportation of Migrants to South Sudan
content: The deportees are stuck in Djibouti amid a legal fight over their expulsions. A lawyer for some of the men said she was concerned for their health and welfare.

title: Cargo Ship Crashed Into Man’s Yard After Crewman Fell Asleep, Police Say
content: A retiree living along a Norwegian fjord woke up on Thursday morning because his neighbor was pounding on his door, telling him to look outside. The ship just missed his house.

title: U.S. to Impose Sanctions on Sudan Over Use of Chemical Weapons
content: The State Department’s announcement comes months after U.S. officials found evidence that Sudan’s military had used chemical weapons against its paramilitary rival.

title: Netanyahu Names Maj. Gen. David Zini as New Domestic Spy Chief
content: The appointment of Maj. Gen. David Zini to head Shin Bet, Israel’s domestic intelligence agency, still faces a fraught legal process.

title: Friday Briefing: Two Israeli Embassy Staff Killed
content: Plus, books to look forward to.

title: After More Than a Century in Skorts and Skirts, Ireland’s Camogie Allows Shorts
content: A committee vote on Thursday approved a measure that would allow players in the women’s sport to choose between shorts or skorts during official play.

title: Trump Makes False Genocide Claims. South Africans Respond With Humor.
content: The jokes mask a deep-seated anger over the legacy of apartheid and the inequality that many Black people say continues to define life in their country.

title: G7 Finance Ministers Show Unity in Support of Ukraine Against Russia
content: Top economic officials avoided a condemnation of U.S. tariffs but committed to trying to reduce “economic policy uncertainty.”

title: Who Is Julius Malema, the South African Politician in the White House Video?
content: President Trump surprised a South African delegation with a video montage of apartheid-era chants from Mr. Malema.

title: Shooting Outside D.C. Jewish Museum Is Part of Global Surge in Antisemitism
content: Groups that monitor hate crimes said the Hamas attack in 2023 and the subsequent war had helped fuel tens of thousands of anti-Jewish incidents globally, including cases of verbal abuse and violence.

title: Simon Mann, Mercenary Who Sought to Overthrow African Ruler, Dies at 72
content: After Eton and a successful career in the British Army, he became, in his words, “the go-to guy for military coups.” The rewards (and risks) were enormous.

title: In Trump Era, Taiwan Defense Chief Says U.S. Still Is a Check on China
content: Wellington Koo says the Trump administration has a shared interest in security in the region, but Taiwan must also ready its own forces for asymmetric warfare.

title: Ukraine Fires Hundreds of Drones at Russia, Moscow Says
content: One of the biggest barrages of the war targeted 10 Russian regions, including Moscow, according to the Ministry of Defense, but it was not clear how much damage the attack did.

title: Forest Loss Around the World Hit a Record in 2024
content: Forests around the world disappeared at a rate of 18 soccer fields every minute, a global survey found. Fires accounted for nearly half of the losses.

title: Inside a Harrowing, Hail-Damaged Flight: ‘We Thought It Was Our Last’
content: When an IndiGo flight from New Delhi ran into a severe hailstorm, a passenger described several terrifying minutes: “They were calling their gods, we were calling our gods.”

title: Gaza Aid Deliveries Begin After Days of Delays
content: The U.N. said about 90 truckloads of supplies had begun to arrive at warehouses and other sites in the devastated territory. It was the first significant influx after a two-month Israeli blockade.

title: Kneecap Member Is Charged With Terror Offense Over Flag at London Concert
content: A member of the Northern Irish rap group Kneecap was accused of illegally displaying a flag in support of Hezbollah. Kneecap denied the offense.

title: Sarah Milgrim and Yaron Lischinsky Were Israeli Embassy Workers Killed in D.C. Shooting
content: Sarah Milgrim and Yaron Lischinsky met while working at the Israeli Embassy in Washington, her father said. Mr. Lischinsky had just bought an engagement ring, an official said.

title: Kim Jong-un Vents Fury After Botched Launch of North Korean Destroyer
content: He vows to punish as criminals those responsible for the failure, in which the ship had its hull torn open and ended up on its side in the water.

title: Israelis, Stunned by D.C. Shooting, Fear Backlash Over Gaza War
content: Political leaders pointed fingers at each other, suggesting that their opponents were responsible for a rise in antisemitism and criticism of Israel.

title: UK Net Migration Almost Halved in 2024, Data Shows
content: Net migration dropped by 50 percent in 2024, data showed Thursday. So why was the prime minister warning of an “island of strangers” earlier this month?
